712024f-a.title: Manhattan: 32nd Street - Broadway
712024f-a.text:
Union Dime Savings Bank on 32nd St. between Broadway and
Sith Ave. before the L was built on 6th Ave.  187S
Back of Grecley Park in foregrouund.
Photo by Brown Brothers
220 Mest 42nd St.
New York City

717395f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
717395f-a.text:
1287-1289 Broadway, west side, between 32nd and 33rd Streets.
This block morphologically belongs to Sixth Avenue, but is given
Broadway house numbering, and hence must be considered the west side
of Broadway.
The Eagle Theatre, in the centre has just recently opened. In
1878 its name will be changed to the Standard Theatre, and it will
finally be replaced by the Manhattan Theatre. This block will be
occupied about 1915 by Gimbel Brothers' department store.
Within a few weeks foundation work will begin on the Sixth
Avenue Elevated Railroad.
Early spring, 1876.
Brown Brothers.

720387f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
720387f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including 32nd Street. In the centre
is the old Seventy-First Regiment Armory Building, which later became
the Herald Building, and now houses a clothing store. In 1928 this
building will be cut in half. The southern half will stand, but
the northern half will be demolished and on its site will be erected
the Herald Square Building.
In the left foreground is Sak's 34th Street, and above it is
R. H. Macy & Company, two large department stores. In the distance
is the Metropolitan Opera House, the Times Building, and the Hotel
Astor.
1923.
ne i C 3o
Ewing Galloway.

720142f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
720142f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north fron, but not including, 32nd Street.
The firet three buildings seen are Gimbel Brothers, Saks-34th Street,
and R. H. Macy & Company, all large department stores.
1926.
Brown Brothers.

717391f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
717391f-a.text:
Domolition of the Union Dime Savings Bank Building, Broadway
at the S.W. corner of 32nd Street. The seven-story John David
Building will be erected on this site.
March 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

717392f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
717392f-a.text:
Hotel Innperial, Broadway at the S.E. corner of 32nd Street.
May 18, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NEG 296G

717394f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
717394f-a.text:
According to the New York Times ofJuly 1, 1939, the above-
mentioned structue has been leased by the Metropolitan lInsurance
Company until December 31, 1949 to a syndicate headed by Frank
WW. Eridel, operator of several other large hotels.
The 80O-room hostelry has been improved and rodernized;
public rooms and some other parts of the building have been air-
conditioned. Many of the original features for which this hotel
is famous have been retained in a more modern setting. The elaborate
Roman-style ceiling is admired by many. It was laii by Italian
workmen brought to this country for this purpose. he inlaid tiles
in the lobby and corridors and the ancient Wynwood Martinique clock
are retained to delight lovers of antiques and clock experts. TThis
clock is perhans the rost interesting decorative piece in the
building. lIt was fashioned by hand by H.T. Crawford, clockmaker to
royalty, in 1691, under a special cormission from Sir. Nalph Wynwood.
In the burnished wood the English craftsman carved the figures of
St. Matthew, standing and kneeling, attended by cherubs around the
dials Mhich still correctly show the hour, the day of the week and
the day of the month. At Sir RalphWynwood's death the fifteen-foot
timepiece ent to the Mittendorf colledticn of clocks in Russia.
It was later boumht for'B,50O by Mrs. Elisaheth C. Cole of New YArk.
William R.H. Martin purchased it in 1911 from the Cole estate to
add to this collection. Later owners were Cornelius Vanderbilt and
and Oliver H.P. Belmont,but Mr. Martin again boumht it to install
in the Broadway hotel which has been in oeration for forty years.

1509101.title: Broadway - 32nd Street - 33rd Street, east side looking southwest
1509101.folder: Broadway - 32nd Street - 33rd Street, east side looking southwest, Manhattan, NY

720143f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 32nd Street
720143f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from 32nd Street. At the extreme
left is seen one of the donkey steam locomotives used on the elevated
lines until 1903, when the "p' was electrified throughout. Also at
the left is the Standard Theatre, originally known as the Eagle Theatre,
which occupies the future site of Gimbel Brother's Department Store.
1896.
Brown Brothers.
